question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: Adopting our vegetable patch cycle across Welsh schools would create a way to reduces food waste as they would get reused as soil and it would help encourage young children to eat their vegetables if they knew they planted them. It would benefit Wales as it would encourage the population to eat healthier and would help the environment by causing less food waste to enter landfills and we would not have to take as many resources from earth because we could just reuse them. It would help the local community as the school could also sell any spare vegetables they grow to the locals. It could help future schools in resource shortages as they could just plant more food.
feedback: Fantastic understanding a really strog answer showing all the understanding of sustainabilty and helping on a local scale.project aims and explaining their design feature

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: One of our features was to have a vegetable patch in the school to provide some of the food for the school dinners. The students could also help and plant the vegetables and knowing that they planted them, it would encourage them to eat the healthy food. We would also take the wasted food from school dinners and put it into a com poster to then put it back into the soil to plant more vegetables, continuing the cycle. This is apart, of the Biosphere and Geosphere sphere systems. They work together since we use the soil made from wasted food to plant the vegetables that then later on become soil again.Our feature would help the environment by making less food waste in the school.
feedback: Fantastic linking of the final design to systems.  Really nice to see link of vegetable gardens etc and the wider impact on climate.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: My project connects to the Earth's natural system because in the classroom there are plants and it would make the children more relaxed. My group added motion detected lights to save electricity bills too! We wanted the real school to be made out of wood because it is more sustainable than bricks since we can re-grow trees. In the school there could be more bins around to stop people littering as well. If we added more water fountains then people could drink water to get more healthy. The positive change is that the school is more sustainable and healthy. Overall the project was fun and I think the atmosphere would be better with some of these ideas.
feedback: Nice links made between design and systems.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: I think if all schools used my chosen feature then it would be more sustainable because the schools are made out of wood and we can re-grow trees. I think that if we add fruits and more water fountains then the school would be more healthy too. If we use the motion detected lights then we would save money for the school to buy more other things.
feedback: Links really well between the idea of where outr materials come from on a global scale to benefits on a local scale.  Also linking lights and energy use to global warming.

question: Q1:  Explain how your chosen design feature connects to Earth's natural systems.
answer: Our design was more of a biosphere, where we created things using old materials while also making it bug and animal friendly, e.g. we had a bug hotel wall,and a massive hedge to both serve as a home and a wall. We also helped the atmosphere by having solar panels creating energy for the kitchen and therefore having less carbon emissions.

question: Q2:  Think about what would happen if all schools in Wales used your chosen feature.
answer: If all schools had the feature or included the idea me and my team made, classrooms would be filled with less carbon dioxide and instead with fresh air that's coming in through convection. This solves the problem with bad air, with too much carbon dioxide it may feel less easy to concentrate and harder to breath from time to time, so if this idea was included then it wouldnt be so hard to breath or focus on the pupil's classwork. When i mentioned focus better, it means that the student could potentially get higher grades, this will impact their future gcses AND what type of college they want to get in.
feedback: Fantastic comunication and explanation on a local scale.  Links to the community and local pupils.
